title: Yasuo is not original (PROOF INCLUDED)
body:
So first off, Yasuo is not a samurai, it was never confirmed and was in fact KNOWN by riot and most that he was a wanderer that seemingly looked like a samurai but was simply a guardian now out of luck without a job. Which also by the way, is a COPIED idea. Here let me provide to you what I mean

Any and everyone that cares to find the truth behind Yasuo's supposed "original concept", search up Vagabond, Manga or Vagabond Musashi Miyamoto

Now, in this manga, which has sold 50+ million copies worldwide, ridiculously successful thus why riot hasn't been called out on it, the creator already made bank, and riot is insignificant in the face of true content creators. This manga stars Musashi Miyamoto who at an early age of 13 "was a wanderer" and was without his parent or "guardian" now "out of luck without a job". See this pattern? Let's continue.

In his case, which is the 1% riot did original is that he is no nonsense wind user, but he was a "samurai looking wanderer at first. Which slowly grew into a Ronin, a rogue masterless, note MASTERLESS!!!, samurai. See? Copied entirely.

The Vagabond was an original tribute and Chanbara to Musashi Miyamoto's accounts of life, all fictional but historically accurate within the manga. 

Notice how very much copied and copyright lacking Riot is? How very sneaky, falsely correct and corrupted they are? I'll leave the rest to the esteemed community.

replies.body: I just want to point out that Miyamato Musashi was a real person, who was famed for DUEL WIELDING. Is Yasuo a duel wielder? No. Is Yasuo a ronin? Also no. A ronin would've required him to have been a samurai or a serf at some point.

Miyamoto Musashi didn't practice Iai either, which is something that is demonstrated in a way by Yasuo's Q.

If you wanted to show where Yasuo's design had its roots, you could easily have said it was based off historical swordsmen from one or more of the several asian countries. Instead, you blatantly accused Riot of plagiarism while using a historical figure who only superficially resembles Yasuo's lore and theme.

Are you serious? Superficially? It isn't. Iaido never existed during his time, he was the founder, he GAVE WAY to Yasuo way of the sword. He was the father of this style, thus it has basis of Dual Wield origin and ronin. Daiymo too. But you don't even get anything, because you're ignorant. Hiragana, Katakana, or Kanji? Which uses English based efforts?

Katakana and Romaji do. 

Yasuo doesn't duel wield. Carrying more than one sword wasn't duel wielding, Miyamoto Musashi was famed for using DUAL wielding, not carrying multiple swords. Many swordsmen carried more than one sword, as it wasn't very hard to damage a katana.

Wrong, wrong and so incredibly wrong. The Katakana and Romaji is correct, that's common sense. Also, he was famous, not only known for that one thing though. Also you just said Swordsmen. I am speaking of SAMURAI. RONIN, DAIMYO'S. They specifically had a Wakizashi and a Katana. Nothing else, maybe a Tachi or a small dagger verison of the Wakizashi, you my friend are poorly informed and mislead entirely.

As you yourself said, Yasuo is not a samurai. If he wasn't a samurai or a serf, he couldn't have been a Ronin. So therefore he's a swordsman. Dual wielding a wakizashi and a katana is still using two at once. Yasuo doesn't use two at once.

If anything, Yasuo is modeled much more closely to Ito Ittosai Kagehisa and not Miyamoto Musashi.

As you say, Yasuo is no samurai, yes you are a broken record. And no, you DO NOT need to be a samurai or serf to become a Ronin, you need be only a swordsmen of great skill. What is Yasuo? A swordsmen of great skill. Closer to a Ronin, and wanderer? Who is also this? Musashi Miyamoto NOT Ittosai, that is your misinformation, look at the skins/trivia on Yasuo, it is even said by riot and their company that he is a reference to MUSASHI MIYAMOTO.

I'm glad I was able to have a discussion with you and see that we do have esteemed people. Please read into this more however, you seem informed on others but not specifically him which is a shame since he is basically the father of all swordsmenship. My thanks, and have a beautiful day/night, I'm off to attend to some business related things. Have fun you guys!

Ronin is defined as a samurai without a lord, and the term originally referred to a serf who abandoned their master. In no place that I can see an etymology, has it ever defined a swordsman in general.

That's because of this. Have you studied Philosophy? Logic? Reasoning? Feudal Japan? The Edo Period? I have. Have you? Are they more than months long?

Actually, Musashi was famous for using whatever he could use to win. Most of his duels he fought with only a single sword, though he did duel wield in a few situations. 

Though this whole thread is ridiculous. A writer drawing inspiration from history? Oh lawdy, lawdy that's not at all what every fucking author ever had done.
Wasn't he also the guy who showed up late to a duel, forgot his sword, and then proceeded to win using one of the oars of the boat he rode to get there?

Yup, except the forgot his sword bit. He knew exactly what he was doing. You see his opponent was an expert with the nodachi which had a large reach advantage on the usual katana also usually sturdier made. He also knew his opponent was known for fits of anger. So he arrived law to piss his opponent off and make him sloppy. Then fought with either an oar or just a longer than usual bokken (wooden practice sword) depending on the version you like. To get rid of the reach advantage and durability issue. 

The fight lasted a very long time with Kojiro almost winning several times. Until the sun set and Musashi used it at his back to blind Kojiro so he could get an advantage and win. It's thought of all Musashi's opponents Kojiro was probably the only one of equal or maybe even greater skill to Musashi himself. But Musashi was underhanded and smarter and that was why he is remembered. 

Of course, I would be amiss to say that the duel itself along with most of the stories of Musashi's life are only known because Musashi wrote them down in books about how great he was. They certainly spread his fame and prestige and he certainly was an accomplished duelist. But a lot of the details are probably exaggerated.
